statement.text: Lymphedema is chronic tissue swelling caused by impaired lymphatic drainage, resulting in interstitial protein-rich fluid accumulation. It is classified as primary (developmental lymphatic abnormality) or secondary (acquired damage from surgery, radiation, infection, or malignancy). Secondary lymphedema is far more common, with breast cancer treatment being the leading cause in developed countries.
statement.formal: Lymphedema: Chronic edema from lymphatic insufficiency; Primary (developmental) vs Secondary (acquired - surgery, radiation, infection); Protein-rich interstitial fluid â†’ fibrosis

explanation.intuition: The lymphatic system is like the body's garbage collection service, removing fluid and proteins that leak out of blood vessels. When this system is damaged or blocked, fluid backs up in the tissues like a clogged drain. Unlike regular swelling (edema), which is mostly water, lymphedema fluid is protein-rich. Over time, these proteins trigger inflammation and scarring, causing the tissue to become permanently thickened and hardened.
explanation.key_insight: Lymphedema is a chronic, progressive condition without cure. Early diagnosis and treatment (before fibrosis develops) offers the best outcomes. The 'Stemmer sign' - inability to pinch a fold of skin at the base of the second toe - is a simple and highly specific clinical test.
explanation.technical_details: Lymphatic insufficiency leads to accumulation of protein-rich interstitial fluid. High protein concentration triggers chronic inflammation, fibroblast proliferation, and adipose deposition. This causes progressive tissue fibrosis and immune dysfunction (increased cellulitis risk). ISL staging: Stage 0 (latent), Stage I (pitting, reversible), Stage II (non-pitting, irreversible), Stage III (lymphostatic elephantiasis).

primary.milroy_disease: Congenital lymphedema - present at birth, VEGFR3 mutation
primary.lymphedema_praecox: Develops during puberty or pregnancy (most common primary type)

secondary.radiation: Lymphatic vessel damage from radiation therapy
secondary.infection: Filariasis (most common cause worldwide), recurrent cellulitis
secondary.malignancy: Tumor invasion or compression of lymphatics

examination.stemmer_sign: Unable to pinch fold of skin at base of second toe/finger - highly specific for lymphedema
examination.location: Usually unilateral in secondary; may be bilateral in primary

staging_isl.stage_0: Latent - lymphatic damage present but no visible swelling
staging_isl.stage_I: Early - pitting edema, reduces with elevation
staging_isl.stage_II: Moderate - pitting may or may not be present, does not reduce with elevation alone
staging_isl.stage_III: Severe - lymphostatic elephantiasis, tissue fibrosis, skin changes

diagnosis.clinical: Usually sufficient based on history and Stemmer sign
diagnosis.lymphoscintigraphy: Nuclear medicine study showing lymphatic transport
diagnosis.icg_lymphography: Near-infrared fluorescence imaging of superficial lymphatics
diagnosis.mri: Can distinguish lymphedema from lipedema or venous edema

surgical.indications: Failure of conservative therapy, recurrent infections, severe QoL impact

definition.@value: Chronic tissue swelling from impaired lymphatic drainage, causing protein-rich interstitial fluid accumulation and progressive fibrosis

clinical_pearls: Stemmer sign positive = lymphedema until proven otherwise
Breast cancer treatment is #1 cause of secondary lymphedema in developed countries
Early treatment before fibrosis = better outcomes - don't delay referral
Compression is lifelong - no cure, only management
